title: Mini Lesson: Setting Up Your Coding Environment

items: Learn what a coding environment is
Choose and install a code editor or platform
Be ready to run Python code in future lessons

sections.heading: What is a coding environment?
paragraphs: A coding environment is where you write and run your code. It’s like the workspace for a programmer. For Python, there are many options — from simple online editors to powerful offline programs.

sections.heading: Option 1: VS Code (Visual Studio Code)
paragraphs: VS Code is one of the most popular code editors. It works on Windows, Mac, and Linux. It’s great for beginners and professionals.
4) Install the Python extension (search 'Python' in Extensions and click Install)

sections.heading: Option 2: Replit (Online)
paragraphs: Replit is a browser-based coding environment — no downloads required. It’s a good choice if you don’t want to install anything yet.
4) Start typing code and press Run

sections.heading: Option 3: IDLE (Comes with Python)
paragraphs: When you install Python on your computer, it comes with a simple editor called IDLE.
3) During install, check 'Add Python to PATH'

sections.heading: Which should you choose?
bullets: VS Code → Best for long-term learning, flexible, and professional
Replit → Quick and easy for trying code without setup
IDLE → Simple, comes with Python, good for offline use
A coding environment is your workspace for writing and running code
VS Code, Replit, and IDLE are three beginner-friendly options
Once you have one, you’re ready for coding lessons

choices: A place where you write and run code
